item.description:
Mr. Maksimov, the town's wealthy recluse, has passed away and many old rumors are swirling about. Some say that he was descended from royalty, others say that he was an adventurer or a smuggler, and there are even those who claim he was a wizard. Whatever they believe, the towns people are wasting no time rushing to his estate sale after his death seeking answers to the mystery around him... and to get their hands on as many of his possessions as they can. Some of Mr. Maksimov's possessions could be worth a fortune but others might end up being worth nothing.

Mr. Maksimov's Manor is played in four rounds. In each of these rounds players will bid on Maksimov's possessions during his estate sale. Item cards that players can gather will either build on each other for more points or cause the player to lose points. When bidding, players need to balance how much value can be gained from the available items with what cards could hurt them. Also, if Mr. Maksimov's will turns up, it could change everything!

Mr. Maksimov's Manor is a casual game that both non-gamers and strategy gamers can appreciate. Casual gamers will enjoy the game's easy to learn rules and the feelings of excitement and anticipation that the game play yields. What will keep strategy gamers coming back is the ability to manipulate the game's odds, constant risk and reward decisions, and subtle elements of social deduction.

One day the Humans had fiddled with the Earth until it could take no more, and the Humans ended. Then the Voles created their civilization and fiddled with the smaller things of the Earth until the Voles ended as well. Now the tiny creatures of the forest compete to find the artifacts and knowledge left by the fallen empires so that they too can mess it all up in their turn.

Each game of Vasty Wilds begins with a randomly placed network of Root cards. The players add cards to the board to expand the forest. Each card placement includes movement and other beneficial effects (Progress) for the player and detrimental effects (Misfortune) for her opponents. A player's opponents are in charge of placing her objectives in inconvenient places on the board. The player who collects all of her objectives first wins.

While Vasty Wilds is easy to learn for younger players or beginners, successive plays will reveal more complex strategies for card placement and effect combinations.

Tofu Kingdom, a.k.a. Princess Legend, is a deduction game involving seven characters. The player assuming the role of Prince Mochi asks each of the other players one question, then guesses which player plays the role of Princess Tofu, the love of Prince Mochi. When answering Prince Mochi's questions, the other players must either lie or tell the truth based on the cards they hold.

The player who Prince Mochi chooses to be Princess Tofu (whether rightly or wrongly) wins the round and receives the number of points specified on their role card. The player who first accumulates 7 points wins.

item.description:
Consuls of Rome depicts the rise of the Roman Republic, from a small city into a large empire.
Players take on the roles of the noble families, who seek to develop the power of their families in the favorable time: the peak of the Roman Republic.

Each player has a deck of cards that depicts celebrities of his family. Some of them are capable of great deeds and some will spoil any project with which they are entrusted — but with a good player's decisions, even those small souls could do a lot for his family.

During the game, players manage the deck of their characters to achieve, in competition with others, as much as possible on each of the planes of life of the Republic.

You are a cluck operator competing in the Cluckbot Fight League International, a brutal realm of mechanical combat as popular as it is illegal. Pick one of 10 cluck models, gather your arsenal, and take them into the arena!

Cluckbot is a board game for 2-player combat dueling. Each player controls a robotic cluck, one of 10 models, each with its own “cluck sheet” defining their attacks, gadgets, grapples and rush combos. You have 8 turns in the pit to eliminate your opponent either through raw damage or forcing them off the stage.

Each turn, players set their cluck’s movement (direction and facing) and action (step or leap) while the opponent does the same, double-blind. After revealing the commands, players resolve actions while spending "charge" to activate weapons and gadgets as they go. The right commands can foil your foe’s assault. Will you lure them under your claws? Outflank? Surprise attack? Strategic planning, anticipating your foe, and a bit of bold improvisation are key to victory!

Elementos is a fast-paced strategy game for two. Rules are easy and quick to learn but unleash a game with surprising strategic depth.

Elementos is about setting traps and thinking ahead. It's a head to head challenge taking place in a natural setting.

The idea behind Elementos is simple. We play in a world of 3 fundamental elements: Fire, water and a tree.. The 3 different elements complete a life cycle; fire takes tree, tree takes water, and water takes fire; the elements create a comfy state of equilibrium. Thing is, each game piece is actually a two faced deceiving character since game pieces can be flipped to reveal a different element on their other side known only to their master.
These elements are potential carriers of your wand, which is the real star of the game.

Be the first player to advance the wand to the other side of the board – and you become an Elemaster, a winner of the game.

The game is portable, and all game parts are made of wood with top quality prints (silkscreened).

name.value: Super PACS: The Game of Politics About the Game of Politics
Super PACS: The Game of Politics About the Game of Politics

item.description:
A Game of Politics about the Game of Politics.

You control one of the aspiring leaders of Humerica and gradually assemble a powerful coalition of factions to help you gain votes, wealth, and power. Each faction gives you a unique exploit that helps you or harms your opponents. Survive unexpected events, strive to win elections, fundraise from your wealthiest factions and, if you like, abscond with the money and purchase investments. The player with the most power wins!

The game features satirical artwork that satirizes American interest groups, voting blocks, and political candidates.

Each player receives a leader card at the start of the game and 5 faction cards. Each turn, a player can 
1. campaign (varies with leader, but usually is draw 1 card) or embezzle (get $2)
2. sneak (play 2 cards face down), exploit (play 1 faction card and use the ability listed on the card), or fundraise (get money equal to your total wealth.)
3. use their leader superpower (this costs money, and some superpowers can be used even when it is not your turn.)

There are 10 rounds. At the end of each round there is an event. Events can have positive or negative effects on players, usually negative. 3 of those events are elections, with the very last event being a presidential election.

Faction cards have three stats: votes, wealth, and power. They also have either an exploit ability (used when "exploiting") or a surprise ability (an effect you get if you discard the card, usually in response to another player doing something).

Money (called MegaBucks) can also be used to purchase investments (there are 4 face up at any time) that vary in how many influence points they give you at the end of the game. Some also let you draw cards immediately or affect vote totals.

Each player develops their board over the ten rounds, adding factions to their coalition of supporters, purchasing investments, trying to win elections, and using the exploit and surprise abilities listed on their faction cards, as well as the superpower listed on their leader, to interfere with opponents or improve their own position.

Designed by Brandon Patton and Andre Pereira. Produced by Tabletip Games in collaboration with Merlin Pool Games.

item.description:
Are you ready to participate in the wildest rally race in the world? In RallyRas, players play in pairs — with one being the driver and the other the navigator — with them trying to complete a circuit as quickly as possible despite their communication problems. Each turn (lap), players must use a keyword to communicate, and the same word with different vowels indicates different things, e.g. "bango" -> right and "bengo" -> left. Each lap, the navigator flips cards with road signs (direction, gear, etc.), then tries to communicate these things to the driver via keywords. (With an odd number of players, the couples change after each turn.)

•••

En RallyRas viviréis pequeños problemas de comunicación. Con ayuda de las cartas los jugadores tendréis que lograr entenderos, recorrer el circuito sin atropellos y llegar a la meta lo antes posible.

¿Preparados para participar en el rally más divertido del mundo? ¡¡Arranca!!

Los jugadores jugarán por parejas, uno será el piloto y otro el copiloto. Con jugadores impares las parejas se alternan cada turno.

Cada turno (etapa) utilizarán una palabra clave, sin una vocal, para comunicarse. Dependiendo con qué vocal la digan y cómo la palabra dará una indicación diferente. (Ej, BANGO -> derecha, BENGO -> izquierda)

En un etapa, el copiloto dará la vuelta a las cartas con las indicaciones de carretera (dirección, marcha y trazada especial) y utilizará la palabra clave para indicar al piloto lo que hay en las cartas.

item.description:
This is a Jenga clone with a die. It consists of plastic bricks in three colors which are stacked up in rows of three, each row containing all three colors.

The active player rolls a die. According to the result s/he now must: 
- pull out one brick in a specific color and stack it onto the top of the tower
- pull out a brick of any color and stack it on top of the tower
- pull out two bricks of any color and stack them on top of the tower
- Lose a turn.

When the tower falls over, the last player to have placed a brick before who didn't topple it is the winner.

You were aboard the yacht "Northern Pride", which a small group of friends had chartered for a party that night off the shores of New England. The group asked the Captain to take the boat way out to sea, away from any lights so they could party under the stars and maybe see the Northern Lights put on a show. When the boat set out, it was a clear, pleasant evening and the sea was calm. The Captain did mention something about a possible storm front that was due to move in early the next morning.

For hours, the party aboard the boat had enjoyed themselves. Then someone noticed the stars had all disappeared, and the stillness of the sea was quickly turning into gale force winds. The storm front had moved in faster than anyone could have expected. A sudden microburst tore the boat to pieces, plunging you all into the sea.

Now you all find yourselves sitting atop a piece of the boat, bobbing in the water, somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean. Scattered in the water all around you, are pieces and debris from the boat. As it all happened so fast, the Captain had no chance to radio for help. You realize it may be some time before you are rescued, and you will need to survive until then.

To survive (and win the game) you must find a flotation device, a signaling device, a water source, and a food source. To find your survival tools, you will have to swim around searching the sea for floating parts. You might even have to might have to steal parts from others, or withhold parts from them to save yourself.

Survive being awash at sea by using deduction, hand management and memory.

This game uses cards as boat pieces, and floating debris. It comes with 6 player tokens to move from card (boat piece or swim card) to card. Each turn you have 2 strokes to move. As the game progresses it takes more strokes to move as the pieces are drifting further apart.

Winter Thunder is a substantial revision of Autumn Mist, an earlier design Brian Train's. Among the many changes are: a newly researched order of battle, with revised counter values and reinforcement schedule; cleaned-up rules including a solitaire play system; and a drastically revised map with a different ground scale and treatment of terrain. Nicely die-cut, two-sided counters and a 17 x 22″ map with nice art by John Cooper!

The system has two main “hooks” to it: an interactive Operations Phase where formation HQs are randomly activated one by one by chit pulls, and take nearby combat units under command to move and fight; and a near-diceless combat resolution system (a d10 is used to check if a particular unit takes casualties, but whether a check is required arises only after comparing attack and defense missions chosen by the players). Brief rules for solitaire play are included.

Released in folio format by Tiny Battles Publishing.

link.value: Autumn Mist: The Battle of the Bulge

name.value: Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #3: Haunted Oak

item.description:
The rumors are true! The Crypt King has shown up on the edge of civilization with a legion of undead. On this border, an old Tavern named Haunted Oak has re-lit it's fires. The Elf Champion and his many allies are starting to fill the tavern and getting ready to face this new threat.

In Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #3 , up to four players take turns collecting heroes and sending them out to gain victory points for your tavern. Each player will try to create a powerful combo of heroes to defeat even the toughest locations.

Only one deck is needed for up to four players; extra decks can be used separately by each player or shuffled together for everyone to share. Game Pack #3 can be played separately or with Game Pack #1 and #2. TCG is for 'the card game'

link.value: Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #1: King's Guard
Character Quest: Heroes The Card Game – Game Pack #2: Savage Beasts

name.value: Our Royal Bones: The Battle of the Bouvines

item.description:
Our Royal Bones recreates the 1214 Battle of the Bouvines using the simple and playable Shields & Swords system. France's King Phillip II Augustus was up against a coalition of German, English, Flemish, and more. Phillip nimbly avoided battle until he could find ideal ground for his cavalry. The result was a humiliating defeat for the coalition that led to the overthrow of Otto IV, and the signing of the Magna Carta by John of England.

This battle isn't just important historically, but makes for an exciting gaming situation. The French have a weak left flank that must be protected at all costs to avoid automatic defeat. The Coalition's center wing has a clear superiority in Infantry, both in terms of quantity and quality, that might just prove decisive.

There are plenty of tactical decisions to be made, and one crucial strategic one: when the French Player declares initiative for the first time, it brings his powerful cavalry reserve-- and that of his opponent-- into play. Do it too soon and the German horse might help turn that vital flank. Wait too long, and they won't turn the tide. Timely deployment is key, and the "right" timing is highly contextual, based on what the players did before and what they do after-- resulting in an engaging and replayable game.

name.value: Surrender Unto Caesar: The Siege of Alesia, 52 BCE

item.description:
Surrender Unto Caesar is the 17th game in the Pocket Battles series of games from LPS, Inc.

Surrender Unto Caesar is a complete mini-game with map and rules (on the back of the postcard) and counters which need to be cut out. Also needed for play is a standard deck of playing cards and 1D6.

The game goes for 4 turns, divided into multiple rounds. Players each draw a card to determine who goes first that round. A turn ends when both Jokers have been drawn from the deck.

The map is divided into Siege Wall Areas (SWA), and each player takes one action (sometimes two actions, occasionally none) in any one SWA. Actions cause combat losses or reduce Roman/Gallic Resistance Levels (RRL/GRL). A player loses once their RL reaches 0. The Gallic player also wins if at the end of any turn Vercingetorix is in a SWA free of Roman infantry units. If the Gallic player hasn't won by the end of turn 4, the Roman player wins.

A competitive board game about being a Viking captain, sailing an uncharted ocean, trying to collect 5 Rune Stones. You can collect Rune Stones either by discovering them in the sea, or by attacking and stealing them from players who have already found them.

Reveal the board as you play by randomly drawing tiles each turn, creating a different sea every game. Aside from Rune Stones, the sea is also filled with islands that can help or hurt (i.e. some islands will kill some of your crew, some islands will provide food for you to feed your crew).

Aside from other players, you also have to contend with the sea itself. You never know when a storm will blow in, knocking your ship off course, or if the mysterious and deadly Ghost Ship will materialize.

From the game box:
"Today is your neighborhood swap meet! Dozens of folks have hauled their unwanted stuff into their driveways. Swap your old stuff you don’t want for… well, more old stuff, but old stuff you’d rather have. Be warned, there are other bargain hunters out there too! Go too slow and you lose the deal. Go too fast and you might miss out on the ultimate swap!"

This game was created as an educational tool to teach students about unit conversion. Players start with certain goods and play cards to convert (swap) those goods into other goods, for example Comic Books to DVDs. Players are competing to complete a Deal by chaining swaps to a shared Goal and collect points based on the number of cards used in the Deal. Play continues for a number of rounds and the player with the most points win.

In Popularity Contest, 4 to 6 players play cards on their turn to try and be the most popular. Being popular is good but beware, sometimes if you are too popular, your friends will turn against you. Play cards to add or subtract from your or an opponents popularity. If you are the least popular you will be eliminated. Don't get too secure in your popularity, if you get too popular someone may give you a zero card and you may also get eliminated.
If you are eliminated, you are not out. Eliminated players use their remaining cards to help determine the winner. Be the last person standing (the most popular) and win the game.

A nice simple and fun game for kids of all ages. Each player spins the wooden wheel to collect robot parts. The first player to assemble his small robot wins. The box contains 1 wooden roller tray, 24 wooden magnetic pieces (4 robots), 1 set of rules.

item.description: In a harbour of an island of the Antilles, 4 ships are to be loaded with goods. Each player wants to attribute his porters to the ships in order to get money when the ship leaves the harbour. In your turn, you must play one of your action cards. The card tells you how many porters you are allowed to attribute to a ship or if you may change their places. If there are as many porters in a ship as the ship needs, it leaves the harbour. All porters earn money. The player who triggered the departure must pay a commission according to the number on his played action card. But if he is the starting player of the round, he may denominate any other player with at least one porter on that ship to pay the commission.

Mix and match dragon, vampire, and werewolf body parts to create a fearsome gladiator that you will pit against your opponents' creations. Fight to the death against the other monsters in a limb rending battle that only ends when one heart remains beating.

The game has two distinct phases, first you draft all of the body parts between all players, and build your monster with the parts you've drafted. Then players take turns attacking each other using an innovative system where the limb you use to attack dictates which area (upper, middle, lower) of your monster will be vulnerable to the next attack aimed at you.

Combat continues as limbs take damage and eventually fall off. If an attack targets a space that is missing a limb it goes through to the torso, once your torso is destroyed you are out of the game.

Each body part has a thematic offensive or defensive battle effect which adds to replay value as you explore all of the possible monster combinations.

item.description:
Description
Ideal for acquiring a good foundation, History in primary school is for young adults, but also looking for a family game or a cultural product for easily dive back into history.
Chronicards, a whole collection to mix !
Each card is unique!

Medal at the Lépine contest.

Contents
60 tarot cards formatted with instructions in French.

How to play ?

Chronicards is a card game played using 60 cards. 
Each card depicts a historical event on one side with explanation and the year in which that event occurred on the other side. 
Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is put in the right place and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.


Description
Conçu en collaboration avec des professeurs des écoles pour une utilisation parascolaire, ce titre s’adresse à un large public à partir de 10 ans.

De Lucy l’Australopithèque (vers -3.000.000) à la mise en circulation de l’Euro (2002), les 60 dates traitent de la Préhistoire et de l’Histoire de France.

Idéal pour acquérir de bonnes bases, L’Histoire à l’école primaire s’adresse aux plus jeunes mais également aux adultes à la recherche d’un jeu familial ou d’un produit culturelermettant de se replonger facilement dans l’Histoire.

Chronicards, toute une collection à mélanger !
Mélangez les thèmes pour enrichir votre chronologie. Chaque carte est unique !

Médaillé au concours Lépine.

Contenu
60 cartes au format tarot avec notice en français.

---

Comment jouer ?

-Preparation de la partie -
Distribuer 5 cartes côté texte visible devant chaque joueur sans retourner les cartes. Les joueurs laissent les cartes posées sur la table. Déposer la pioche côté texte visible et retourner la première carte du paquet côté date sur la table. C'est le point de départ de la chronologie.

-Déroulement-
À tour de rôle, chaque joueur choisit une carte dans son jeu en énonçant à voix haute le titre de l'événement. Il la positionne ensuite chronologiquement par rapport à celle(s) déjà déposée(s). Il retourne alors la carte côté date pour vérifier s'il a raison. Si oui, il ne pioche pas de carte. Si non, la carte est repositionnée au bon endroit dans la frise chronologique et le joueur pioche une carte. C'est ensuite au joueur suivant. Si un joueur ne se souvient plus de l'événement correspondant à une carte déjà posée, il peut la retourner pour la consulter.

-Fin-
Le premier à se débarrasser de toutes ses cartes l'emporte. Si des joueurs terminent dans le même tour, ils continuent à jouer en piochant une nouvelle carte et sont éliminés en cas d'erreur. Le dernier encore en jeu gagne.

Publisher Blurb:

Baseball Highlights: 2045 is like watching TV highlights of early 21st-century baseball games, with the gameplay being full of theme with no outs or innings and without bogging down in a play-by-play baseball simulation. In this quick and interactive game, two players build their teams as they play, combining both strategy (building your team) and tactics (playing the game) without any of the downtime. Game includes regular head to head play as well as solitaire and 3 player variants and the means to play 4 player tournaments. The game also supports combining boxes for even larger tournaments. 1-4 players 45 minute play time. The Super Deluxe Edition comes with seven mini expansions: Magna Glove, Pitches, Cyborg Hitters, Robots Rally Cap, Coach, Big Fly!, and Errors!.

link.value: Baseball Highlights: 2045 – Naturals & Magna Glove Expansion

item.description:
Bezzerwizzer Musik uses the same rules as Bezzerwizzer Kompakt but contains only questions regarding music.

The game contains 100 cards with questions in 12 music categories and therefor only 1.200 questions - less than previous versions. Both question cards and category tokens are kept in an orange color to make them distinct from the original BEZZERWIZZER game and BEZZERWIZZER Kompakt. This means that you can mix tokens from all of the games together and create your own game with precisely the categories you like.

The rules below are an exact copy of the ones from Bezzerwizzer Kompakt:

To start with the players are divided into two to six teams. Each team can consist of one or more players. Each team then gets a bezzerwizzer token that can be used once per round (see below).

Now the game starts: Each team picks a token at random out of the included bag. There are 20 tokens - one for each category in the game. The token must be kept secret for the other players. The first team to go then choose either to answer a question in the category on their token or to swap with one of the other teams without knowing what they will get. If they answer the question that they end up with correctly, they will receive 3 points - a wrong answer does nothing. Scoring is kept on the included pad. This continues till all teams have answered a question. The last team will not have the possibility to swap as all other teams have used up their categories.

Each turn each of the teams have one opportunity to bezzerwizze one of the other teams question. This means that if the team does not answer the question correctly the team that has bezzerwizzet has a chance to answer as well. If the first team does answer correctly however the others team will have wasted their chance to bezzerwizze. The number of points you get for bezzerwizzing and answering correct is dependent on at what time you choose to do it. If you choose to bezzerwizze after the category is revealed but before the question is read aloud you will get 2 points for a correct answer. If you do it after the question has been read aloud you will only get 1 point. If the teams that bezzerwizzet can not answer correctly either the original team will receive the points.

The turn order then switches one place and the process starts again. If there are fewer category tokens in the bag than the number of teams when a new turn is started all of the tokens are returned to the bag.

The game ends when one of the teams have 20 points (the round is finished to allow other teams to reach 20 as well). Alternately you can choose to only play until the bag is empty.

Smarten-Up is a game based on health and nutrition. The game consists of 6 packs of question and answer cards with 48 cards in each deck, 1 die, 2 score pads, 1 pen, and one rule/reference sheet. Each deck has a different colour back and a different point value.

The players roll the die to determine which deck to draw from. The starting player asks the question on the card to the player on the left. If the player answers the question correctly, they earn the full point value of the card. If the player fails to answer correctly, the asking player may score half of the point value themselves, or ask the question of the player on the first player's left. If that player answers the question correctly, they score full points. If the player fails to answer correctly, the asking player scores full points (except for true and false questions).

Some cards are bonus cards. The asking player reads the cards and gives the points to the player on the left. These two players then exchange places. This eliminates any possible preferred table positions. The game ends at a predetermined time or when a predetermined point value is reached. The player with the highest score is the winner.

Casper's cousin Spooky, the tuff little ghost, haunts this simple marble maze game. The Maze is made of cardboard with cardboard tabs that are pressed down to form bumpers for the marbles to dodge. The top of the box is placed under one end of the box bottom so the maze is angled down. Game comes with five marbles.

In turn, players take and play ALL of the marbles by dropping them into one of the holes at the top of the maze. The marbles must be held one inch above the hole when dropped. The player receives points as the marble lands in one of the slots at the bottom of the maze. If a player gets a marble in each of the slots at the bottom of the maze on one turn, they get a 10 point bonus. If a player gets all the marbles stacked into one slot at the bottom of the maze, they get a 10 point bonus. First player to 100 points wins.

Somewhere outside your safe nest there is a tasty cheese. The catch is that the stupid humans have not only placed it in a maze but also that the maze keeps changing. Nevertheless, you want that cheese, even if it means that you have to face dangerous traps. Beware, there are other mice in the maze as well and they may trick you to leave the cheese in their nests instead.

For each cheese that you take to your private nest, you score 1 point. For each cheese that you take to a shared nest, the players of the adjacent private nests score 1 point each. The player with the most points when all cheeses have been taken or no more actions are possible wins.

The game starts with 7x7 maze tiles, of which only the central one (the Cheese Chamber) is turned face up. The players start with 1 maze tile each. Each turn, a player does the following:

1. Move your mouse as far as you can along the path. In a nest, you may choose not to move, and in the Cheese Chamber, you may choose through which exit you move.
2. Move marbles as far as they can along the path. Marbles are traps that return mice to their nests and cause them to lose 1 turn.
3. Replace a maze tile anywhere in the maze by placing the one on your hand face up. If the maze tile you replace is turned face up, the next maze tile you replace must be turned face down.

When you leave the Cheese Chamber, you take a cheese, and when you enter a nest, you leave the cheese there, even if it is not a nest of your own. If you are hit by a marble, the cheese is left in the maze, and if you pass another mouse, you exchange whatever you carry. If you move out of the maze, you return to your nest and loses one turn while the cheese is returned to the Cheese Chamber. If the path is a loop, neither mice or marbles move.

The combination of free placement of maze tiles and forced movement through the maze creates a strong take that mechanism. Not only can you prevent other mice from finding the cheese but you can even force them to take it to your own nest. When you place a maze tile, each other player gets to place a maze tile so you must be very careful when moving in the maze!

item.description:
Thievery is a board game where players assume the roles of Spymasters in a fictional world where condemned souls are syphoned. This world is simply called "The Town" and every player participates in expanding it in order to take a piece for themselves... By force or otherwise.

As players expand the Town, they will claim special Territories as their own, which will later grant them advantages over other players. Some of these Territories will allow players to purchase enchanted weaponry, lethal skills, or even grant their owners an income boost.

The Town is expanded by each player with 3 different tiles - Roads, Markets and Buildings. These serve as space for the unit to move through and players to claim territory over (by placing faction-coloured territory cards over, directly).

Thievery, as the name suggest, revolves around coin management and manipulation. You can steal from enemy units just as well as you can steal from their lands. Your Thieves will help you with all your cunning needs, your Thugs keep the enemy out. And your Rogues, well... They specialise in keeping the enemy out of Town, permanently.

There are several ways to win the game. Either a player places all of their faction's territory cards, or they manage to capture all their enemies' territories before they can expand too much. Another way to win is to count victory points at any given time for claimed territories, recruited units and gathered coins.

Once upon a time there was someone who loved telling stories... well if you know that someone, then they'll be a winner at playing The Story Telling Game! Whether they tell tall, short, fairy or scary stories, this fast-paced game will be a best-seller for children aged six upwards who have a vivid imagination, a competitive streak and are quick thinking. The Story Telling Game is a great birthday and Christmas gift and it not only encourages creativity, but it will keep children entertained on rainy days and school holidays. Created for budding Jackanorys, The Story Telling Game sees each player start with five words on their cards and when the clock starts, the first players starts telling a story using one of their words. Then it's the turn of the next player who has to incorporate one of their words into the former player's story... and so it goes on with each player adding to the story with one of their words at a time until the buzzer declares that it's 'The End' for the player who's talking when the buzzer sounds. When this happens, the player has to pick up all the cards used by the other players and begin a new story, this time with the opening 'Twice upon a time'. The story doesn't have to win awards or be a work of literary genius - it can be about anything but has to include one of the words on each of their cards. The Smiley Trump card adds a twist to the game as it can be used as any word and if a player is caught out by the buzzer, the Smiley Trump means they get off scot-free and the next player has to collect all the cards.

item.description:
In Pacal's Rocket, each player build pyramids in the districts of the ancient Maya town Palenque. According to the dice roll of the actual round, the player moves his starship, a pipe. After the movement, a player may throw 1 energy stone of his own color into his starship and under certain restrictions another one into an opponent's starship. When starting the movement, any energy stones in the starship will stay on the board.

A player may build a pyramid if his energy stones are placed in a certain constellation on the board. In this case, he builds the pyramid and afterwards takes back his used energy stones.

For building a pyramid, the player gets victory points if he is the first builder in the district or gains the majority.

The world's most beloved beagle is back! A legend in his own mind. Snoopy takes off as the Flying Ace in constant pursuit of his nemesis; The Red Baron. It's high-flying fast-paced fun around the Eiffel Tower as Woodstock and his team of mechanics lend support from the ground. Pick up the most tiles to win!.

name.value: Chronicards: Les grandes inventions et découvertes scientifiques

item.description:
Description
Ideal for acquiring a good foundation, The great scientific inventions and discoveries is for young adults, but also looking for a family game or a cultural product for easily dive back into discoveries.
Chronicards, a whole collection to mix !
Each card is unique!

Medal at the Lépine contest.

Contents
60 tarot cards formatted with instructions in French.

How to play ?

Chronicards is a card game played using 60 cards. 
Each card depicts a great discovery or invention on one side with explanation and the year in which that event occurred on the other side. 
Players take turns placing a card from their hand in a row on the table. After placing the card, the player reveals the date on it. If the card was placed correctly with the date in chronological order with all other cards on the table, the card stays in place; otherwise the card is put in the right place and the player takes another card from the deck.

The first player to get rid of all his cards by placing them correctly wins. If multiple players go out in the same round, then everyone else is eliminated from play and each of those players are dealt one more card for another round of play. If only one player has no cards after a bonus round, he wins; otherwise play continues until a single player goes out.


Description
Conçu en collaboration avec des professeurs des écoles pour une utilisation parascolaire, ce titre s’adresse à un large public à partir de 10 ans.

Idéal pour acquérir de bonnes bases, Les grandes inventions et découvertes scientifiques s’adresse aux plus jeunes mais également aux adultes à la recherche d’un jeu familial ou d’un produit culturel permettant de se replonger facilement dans les découvertes.

Chronicards, toute une collection à mélanger !
Mélangez les thèmes pour enrichir votre chronologie. Chaque carte est unique !

Médaillé au concours Lépine.

Contenu
60 cartes au format tarot avec notice en français.

---

Comment jouer ?

-Preparation de la partie -
Distribuer 5 cartes côté texte visible devant chaque joueur sans retourner les cartes. Les joueurs laissent les cartes posées sur la table. Déposer la pioche côté texte visible et retourner la première carte du paquet côté date sur la table. C'est le point de départ de la chronologie.

-Déroulement-
À tour de rôle, chaque joueur choisit une carte dans son jeu en énonçant à voix haute le titre de l'événement. Il la positionne ensuite chronologiquement par rapport à celle(s) déjà déposée(s). Il retourne alors la carte côté date pour vérifier s'il a raison. Si oui, il ne pioche pas de carte. Si non, la carte est repositionnée au bon endroit dans la frise chronologique et le joueur pioche une carte. C'est ensuite au joueur suivant. Si un joueur ne se souvient plus de l'événement correspondant à une carte déjà posée, il peut la retourner pour la consulter.

-Fin-
Le premier à se débarrasser de toutes ses cartes l'emporte. Si des joueurs terminent dans le même tour, ils continuent à jouer en piochant une nouvelle carte et sont éliminés en cas d'erreur. Le dernier encore en jeu gagne.

In Halloween, players play the role of dark lords recruiting minions across a graveyard. Whoever recruits the best army of undead will win the game.

MATERIAL

- 80 counters (headstones) in 4 colours (20 each of red, blue, yellow, green).
- 4 dark lords (red, blue, yellow, green)
- A deck of 36 mini-cards with the following structure:

-- The back of the cards shows a closed grave. There are 4 colours of graves (9 each of white, gray, black, brown).

-- For each grave colour, there are these fronts: 2 zombies (4 points each), 2 skeletons (3 points each), 2 ghosts (2 points each), 3 will-o'-the-wisp (1 point each).

GAMEPLAY OVERVIEW

Shuffle the whole deck and place the 36 cards facing down forming a 6x6 grid. This is the graveyard.

Players take turns moving their Dark Lord and claiming graves. When claiming a grave, the card is turned facing up. Players can also use their will-o'-the-wisps to inspect unclaimed graves.

The game ends when all cards have been revealed. Each player then adds up the value of his claimed cards. The highest score wins.

item.description: One day, a safe suddenly appears in the castle ruins - but what is the code to open it? Luckily, the four amateur detectives keep on finding cards with pictures on them on their way through the city, which lead them to the code numbers. How is it done? Think of a word that describes the card and break it down into syllables in order to move the figures. Crack the code with a sharp mind and a feel for language!

Contains board with 2 sides for 2 different games to play "with" your Charmin' Chatty Cathy doll: Chatty At The Fair and Chatty Skate 'N Slide. Includes a record to insert into the Charmin' Chatty doll so she talks during the game. (Child can play games alone & doll can be the second player, or up to 4 players can play)

The first game is Chatty Skate 'N Slide: Play this game with the skates attached to the playing pieces and use side 1 of the record. Begin on the Start space, Chatty moves first. Pull the Chatty-Ring all the way out and let go. Chatty will say "Race to Orange", "Move ahead to Yellow", etc. Player will go to the next space of the color indicated. If Chatty says "Race to Orange and Slide", move to the next space of that color and use the slide if there is one. You cannot use the slide if Chatty does not say so. If Chatty says "You cannot move!", you cannot move on that turn. The winner is the first player to get to the winning "End" circle. Chatty must call one of the colors in the circle: red, orange, yellow or green, whether she says slide or not.

The second game is Chatty At The Fair: Use the playing pieces without the skates and use side 2 of the record. Child starts on My Start space and Chatty starts on Chatty's Start space. (When 3 or 4 play, 2 start on My Start and the rest start on Chatty's Start) Pull the Chatty-Ring all the way out. She will say HOW TO TRAVEL to the World's Fair. ("Why not ride the Pony?", "Go take the Whirlybird", "Go by Choo Choo Train", "Get in the Car and go", "Take the red Ferryboat", or "Take the Jet Plane - zoom!") Move to the next picture on the players path that matches what Chatty says. If Chatty says "Stop to see the sights", player does not move. If Chatty says "Green Light, go ahead 3" player moves ahead 3 picture spaces. Winner is the first player to get to their winner space (Whirlybird for My Start path and Choo Choo train for Chatty's Start path) (If player is 1 to 3 spaces from the winner space and Chatty says "Green Light, go ahead 3" player moves to the winner space and wins.)

This Kickstarter-exclusive edition contains, in addition to all the contents of the base game, the mini expansion "Tiny Epic Galaxies: Satellites & Super Weapons Mini Expansion".

From the description of Tiny Epic Galaxies:

A thirty-minute game of galactic conquest, Tiny Epic Galaxies is driven by an exciting dice-rolling mechanism that rewards thoughtful programming of the results. Players control a home galaxy and a fleet of space ships. As players upgrade their galaxies, they gain access to more ships and more dice.

Each turn, a player rolls a set of dice; how many dice are rolled is determined by the level of that player's galaxy. Each side of the six-sided die represents a different type of action: Movement, Colony Action, Harvest from Culture Planets, Harvest from Energy Planets, Improve an Economic Influence, and Improve a Diplomatic Influence.

After the roll, the player sorts the results of the roll (one selective re-roll is allowed) and organizes the dice in a desired activation order. Each die, in order, is then resolved and the results are immediate, which allows the player to pull-off unseen combos and surprise other players. Other players have the option to copy other player's actions...at a cost!

As players expand their galaxy by colonizing other planets through economic and diplomatic influence, they gain victory points AND the special powers brought in by those planets! In addition to galaxy upgrades, effective resource management provides luck-mitigating options that can sway the game in a calculated player's favor.

Whoever achieves the most points from acquiring planets and upgrading their personal galaxy wins!

item.description:
(From the back of the box)

Get Ready for 9 Innings of Fun!

In Bases Loaded, each roll of the dice represents an At Bat.

Out-Roll your opponent on offense to hit doubles, triples, and even home runs!

Utilize the strategy cards to steal bases, bunt and more!

With two different ways to play, Bases Loaded is fun for all ages!

Bases Loaded is a simple simulation of baseball. One player is "at-bat" and one player is "in-the-field". The both roll three six-sided dice and the highest roll uses their dice result to determine the outcome. It's a single for the "at-bat" player and an "out" for the "in-the-field" player. There are special results on rolls of doubles (two dice having the same number) and triples (all three dice having the same number) for both players (provided they win the roll off).

The come comes with a LARGE set of cardboard stand-up players that are moved around the bases. However, there is no "outfield" players.

In the "advanced" rules, both players are given a set of "one-use" cards which can also affect play. For the "at-bat" player these are: Stolen base x2, Balk x1, Sacrifice x3, Hit by pitch x2, Walk x4, Bunt x2, Double x3, Triple x1 and Home run x2.

For the "in-the-field" player these are: Ground out x4, Pick off x3, Fielder's choice x4, Double play x4, Triple play x1 and Bring it back x2.

That's pretty much it. Other than choosing when to use which card there are not many decisions to make and no way to influence the dice rolled, so that parts primarily luck.

A simple family game with nice components.

In this silly twist on Charades, players take turns placing one or two sock puppets on their hands and creatively act out as many of the three items on their card that they can get through before the sand timer runs out. The puppets come with holes on the side and the thumb and pinky are used as arms. The game also comes with small props to help act out the words on the cards. All of the other players try to guess what is being acted out. Both the actor and the correct guesser score points when items are guessed. The player with the most points after the designated number of rounds is the Puppet Master!

Ran an die Rohre - wer ist der schnellste Klempner?

Wer von euch schneidet seinen Mitspielern clever den Weg ab oder blockt gekonnt deren Leitung? Verlegst du am schnellsten deine Pipeline kreuz und quer uÌˆber dem Spielbrett? Lass es rocken und nimm die Herausforderung an!

Ein Spiel von HCM Kinzel ab 4 Jahren

				
					===========

Underneath, upward, through the middle!

Which one of you will cleverly cut off your fellow players or skillfully block their way? Will your pipeline be the fastest to crisscross across the board? Rock on and take on the challenge!

Each player is given a set of pipes in their colour along a starting pipe coming out of the board. On a turn, the active player rolls the die, which shows the various pipe shapes available, picks up the corresponding piece, and extends his pipeline (or blocks his opponents' if he rolled a dead-end!) Once per game, he may connect his pipeline to the floor to immediately get another turn. The game ends once a player wins by connecting his starting spot to one of the two spots in his colour across the board.

Goat War has broken out! 
As such, the goats have been prepared and reinforced to carry their army to the victory.

Goat Army is a strategic and cooperative card game where you challenge your friends to a battle with armoured and crazy goats. NSFW deck available!

Roll Call (Spill and Spell) is an ALL-PLAY letter dice game where you CALL IT AS YOU SEE IT! ROLL out the 22 letters and 7 category dice. Then, CALL out the first words you can make that fit the given category. For every Category you CALL out, you collect that die. Once all category dice are earned, its time to ROLL and CALL again! First player to earn 20 points is the winner!

Barbie: Bring the Bling Game includes 24 glamtastic rings. Take em, Wear em, Swap em. 2 Pinktastic shades included. Pinktastic Shades reveal a secret design that can be seen when sunglasses are on.

The object is to get at least one ring of each of the four Barbie icons to win. To play, put all of the rings face down in the center of the play area. The first player puts the Barbie sunglasses on and spins, following the instructions on the spinner. The sunglasses are only passed to another player when indicated by the spinner. The spinner may indicate passing the sunglasses, taking the sunglasses, drawing a ring or passing a ring. Any time a player thinks she has one ring of each of the Barbie icons she can say Bling. The other players take turns looking at the rings with the sunglasses on to see if she is right. If she is correct, she wins. If she is not, she puts one ring back in the middle and play continues.

Summary:

Neo-Hunt 3 is a round-based, multi-phase board/card game for 2-4 players. Each player controls a team of three "varans" (large, humanoid reptiles bio-engineered for combat). Players try to kill as many "troopers" and opponents as possible before one team is eliminated. Opponents include the varans of other players as well as "troopers" (non-player game tokens) who occupy the game board and arrive at the beginning of each turn.

Setup:

Each player selects a color and takes all the pieces for that color. Players sit on corners of the playing surface. The game board randomly is generated by creating a 3x3 grid from the board pieces. Each of the nine sectors of the game board provides various terrain benefits or penalties. During the game a total of fifty "troopers" will deploy into various sectors and players may move their varan units into sectors.

Game Play:

Play proceeds in turns. During turn setup, each player selects and plays four action cards. Then play proceeds in player order, with each player in sequence executing their four played action cards. Action cards are resolved in the order of priority indicated on their face; they may distribute damage tokens. Damaged "troopers" are eliminated and varans with enough accumulated damage tokens also are eliminated. After each player has taken their phase all "troopers" take automatic actions of either shooting at a visible varan or, if no varans are visible to them, by moving to a new sector. At the end of each turn new "troopers" deploy onto the board if any counters remain.

The game continues until end of turn when there are no more trooper counters on the board or one varan team has all its members killed. When game ends, the player with most points wins. If tied, the one with most surviving varans, and if still tied, tied victory.

User Comments:

The game is print-and-play and published for free access via HTML. Components and rules are downloadable in PDF format. Color printing is recommended.

User summary:

Neo-Combat is a card game using print-and-play materials. Players hold "Varan" cards, which represent a combatant reptilian humanoid controlled by the player. Players also draw, hold, and play "Action" cards that drive the game. Varan cards are always played on the table but begin play in the "Cloaked" (face down) position. Varans remain "Cloaked" until play dictates otherwise, when they are turned face up and thus become much more vulnerable.

The playing surface is divided into Sectors which join in a central "Battlefield" Sector. Play involves moving Varan cards between Sectors and playing Action cards to evolve maneuvers. The goal of the game is to eliminate all of the other players' Varan cards. Played Action cards and defeated Varan cards go into Discard.
A card game platform using word parts (roots, prefixes and suffixes) to find, build and reform words across several games of varying length and complexity.

item.description:
Pan for gold in this unique worker placement game!

Welcome to the town of Coloma! Players play the role of gold miners that have arrived in Coloma, Montana in 1848 upon hearing of the chance discovery of gold in the surrounding area. As one of the first prospectors to arrive you have a head start on the swarm of fortune seekers heading west and a great opportunity to become some of the biggest Gold Mining Tycoons in America!

During the early stages of the game the players have no workers and must Placer Mine the rivers by themselves, panning for small deposits of gold. By the end of the game the players may have built a street of buildings in the town of Coloma funded by a successful gold mining operation in the mountains, employing a team of hopeful workers to produce dozens of gold bars and amassing a fortune!

What makes the game unique is the mechanic that allows players to simulate gold panning using the game box and the double sided 'Alluvium' chits.

name.value: Lalaloopsy: Find 'N Seek – Memory Match Spinning Game

item.description:
A neat game is the Lalaloopsy Find N’ Seek – Memory Match Spinning Game. As the name suggests, this game is played to enhance the memory of the child by making him/her remember the images on the play card and then matching the image with those of the other cards. The game consists of 1 console, 8 chunky play cards, 1 mix up card, and 1 free spin card. The game also improves hand eye coordination since the children need to pick up the cards to see the images.

A fun interactive memory game for kids!

Pull the handle to make their matches! Your children will improve their memory skills and hand eye coordination with Lalaloopsy Find ‘n Seek!

The Zombie Plague is decimating humanity. In a last ditch attempt to save the species, the governments of the world have turned to you and your peers: ‘scientists’ who believe that Healing Crystals or Magnets can cure anything.

You’ve only got 8 rounds to work out which cures might work and collaboratively build enough evidence to cure the plague - but watch out, only those who’ve backed the right cure will win the Nobel Prize, the others are prepared to take the whole human race down to stop you shaming them.

Zombology is played over eight rounds, each round players choose a card from their hand to either contribute to the eradication of the disease by performing research in one of six therapies or to play an event either boosting one of the therapies or overrunning an opponent's lab with zombies. The remaining cards in their hand are then drafted to the next player, so players build up a picture of which therapies might offer a cure as the game goes on. Therapy cards range in value from 1 to 6 and can only be played if any player has played the card below it (i.e. playing a four requires a 3 in that therapy in play) and then game ends when one or more 6s are played in a round. Players work together, trying to cooperatively generate enough evidence for a cure, but not everyone will win - only those who have backed the right cure will be lauded, or everyone might die!

The Terrifying Girl Disorder is a quirky and brain-burning set-collecting card game. The deck consists of seven different types of cards, with each type represented by a girl with numbers 1–7 and a special power. Players start with a hand of cards, and each round play any number of identical cards from hand, activate that girl's special power, then collect new cards, using a weird drafting mechanism.

Each player can play a certain numbered set only once per game. When the game ends, the player who has played the most cards of a certain girl "becomes" that girl. Each different girl has a completely different way of scoring, so you need to adapt to the other player's play rapidly.

(The title is an allusion to a novel set in a distant future in which girls around the world start manifesting supernatural powers, and they are more or less treated as threats to humanity.)

name.value: Legend of the Galactic Heroes: Side Stories

item.description:
Science fiction wargame set in the universe of the Legend of the Galactic Heroes. This set covering 3rd and 4th battle of Tiamat Star zone.

Two scenarios are contained in the game, and the fictional space battle that each was drawn in the story is reproduced. These are being called a fleet battle, but when either is said, it is close to the land battle of Napoleonic age.

Each player control one or more star fleets. 
Each fleet is commanded by one admiral, and organized by 6 to 14 ships units.

Each turn, a fleet are activated in the unintentional order by chit-pull system, and it resolves a movement and a combat. 
An average admiral has only one or two chits. But the heroes of the story has four or more chits, and it is activated many times during one turn. 
A battle is resolved with adjacent hex on the Odds CRT.

item.description:
Burger Up is a card matching puzzle game about the art of burger making. Fill orders, earn prestige and be the best burger chef around!

Players strive to become the most prestigious restaurant by building the biggest Burgers and by using the best ingredients.

Players take turns, which consist of four phases: the Market phase where players may purchase ingredients from the market, the Building phase where players place up to 3 ingredients on their burgers, the Burger Up! phase where players may score their burgers if they satisfy an order and the clean-up phase where players draw back up to 4 cards.

The game ends when no more Order cards can be revealed. A bonus is awarded to the Chef who built the most burgers and then the winner is determined, based on who has earned the most coins.

item.description:
Welcome to Anytown, U.S.A. where people grumble about the quality of their health care but still show up at Healthy Heart Hospital hoping they made a smart decision. Much has been said (and even more has been written) about the previous administration’s haphazard management of Healthy Heart. In an effort to save the Hospital, you and your allies among its leading Physicians have staged a recent “Clinical Coup” and taken over the Hospital to restore its prestige. However, actually managing things from the inside is never as easy as it appears from the outside, and juggling the responsibilities at Healthy Heart Hospital can quickly turn even the noblest healer into a money-grubbing pragmatist cynically looking for a place to hide the victims of your “care.”
 Does your team have what it takes to bring Healthy Heart Hospital back to its former glory without becoming Hard Hearted in the process?
 Healthy Heart Hospital is a cooperative game for 1 to 5 players, played in rounds, with each player spending actions to treat and (hopefully) cure the various patients that come pouring into the hospital each round. Patients are represented by a number of cubes of various colors. Color represents the type of illness, while the number of cubes represents the severity of the illness.

item.description:
"It is the near future; Earth. Years ago, scientists successfully constructed the Belief Engine, a machine that warps reality based on peoples’ strongly held beliefs. The machine was turned on for testing, but it proved too sensitive: widespread belief in the depravity of man and fears of social collapse suddenly took on the full force of objective fact, and science skepticism rendered the Engine’s creators helpless to intervene. Without resort to a shared external reality, civilization crumbled like a sand castle in the tide.

"From the ruins have now arisen cults led by charismatic, messianic figures possessed of seemingly divine powers derived from the still-functioning Engine. You are one such a figure—the true one, the Messiah. It is God’s will that you build temples and marshal followers, then mold their beliefs to perform miracles and destroy your rivals. They’ll be doing the same, but don’t worry–God is on your side…"

Awards and Honors


 SXSW Gamer’s Voice Award Nominee, 2018
 Indie MEGABOOTH Tabletop Three-time Official Selection
 Indiecade Official Selection, 2016
 Geekwire Indie Game Highlight, PAX West 2016


How it's played

Rounds go player by player, with each individual player turn broken up into phases:

1) Beginning (reset any praying followers to active status; recruit followers and build temples; draw back up to 6 cards);
 2) Action (move units, have followers on temples pray to produce belief, use belief to perform miracles);
 3) Combat (adjacent enemy units attack one another according to deterministic rules);
 4) End (discard down to 3 cards, loot any empty enemy temple you have units left adjacent to, make sure you have enough units left to support the continued functioning of your own temples).

Each round ends with the Market, in which players make secret bids on an assortment of 5-7 miracle cards. Bidders get to spend their bid on up to 2 cards, with high bidders buying first. Purchased cards are placed into each player's discard pile, eventually to be cycled back into their decks Dominion-style.

A player wins by slaying an enemy messiah, by reducing an enemy to less than 4 followers, by capturing an enemy's holy city, or by reducing an enemy to less than 8 miracle cards.

"Endless tunnels, endless battle, endless death...

I awoke among my species, mine folk. I have risen, understood, grasped and taken my power, those below my slaves! I shall raise great armies to massacre any enemy! These territories are mine, only the weak to destroy! Shadow deities pretend to stand above me, but I shalt not kneel. I shall sit on any throne!

Tonight I am Warlord, an oath declared! The weak and shoddy I shall craft into powerful warriors, warriors into command, command into my Lord of all Battles! Together we conquer! Our species will rule the caverns of black! Into the Warrior Path!"

Cave Evil: Warcults is a stand alone game. Players who own Cave Evil can expand their game with Warcults. It can be played either as an individual game or as an expansion.

Players who own Cave Evil have the liberty to play as only a Warlord, only a Necromancer or both.
Players who own Warcults will begin as a Warlord, but they will be able to connect each future Corroded Corridor to this issue.

GAMEPLAY
As we learned in CAVE EVIL, a Necromancer can weave a web of control over 6 Squads, but their power does not end there. While they may dominate 6 squads, others may swear their allegiance to the infernal magi. The cave is endless. Battles for territory will forever ensue. The forbidden wizards must raise troops from their species, create Warriors from the weak and shoddy, inspire Command and demand the allegiance of their greatest Warlord. The warrior path begins!

Warcults is an introduction to a Warrior Path - the first expansion for CAVE EVIL.

A Warrior path is a way to play Cave Evil. It is a modified Sequence of Play to accommodate players that prefer to play with just a Warlord Character or with both a Warlord and a Necromancer.

The Warlord is a branch of Necro command and is under the allegiance of a Necromancer. The Necromancer is NOT needed to play!

A Warlord commands an army and the divisions of command below them.
Apart from WARCULTS features, the game introduces new actions and adjustments to the overall Sequence of Play.

Victory is dependent on each scenario.

This is educational memory game.
a kind of Ogura Hyakunin Issyu:Japanese ancient card game

There are 100 pair pictures in the game.
Player can play "Old Maid","Concentration" using the cards.
there are hints printed on the cards.
if you know 100 famous ancient Japanese poems , you can win easily.

and you can play traditional Ogura Hyakunin Issyu too.

Heisei Hyakuninn Issyu is compatible.

Ogura is a Japanese place, and Hyakunin mean 100 people. Issyu: one poem. So, the tile means 100 poets who are picked by famous poet Sadaie(Teika) FUJIWARA at Ogura.

The poem is written in ancient Japanese language. Many Japanese students have to memorise 100 poems even if the poem sounds like Greek.

Naturally Disastrous is a 1-6 player co-operative dice driven game of peril and adventure. Your mission is simple enough. Arrive at your destination, verify the conditions and then set up a long range communication array to deliver your findings back to your superiors. Easy, right? Your visit to Earth is supposed to just be a quick investigation into how the planet is doing.

As you enter the atmosphere massively destructive storms make it hard to navigate. Giant volcanoes, earthquakes, thermal gas explosions and flooding are rampant and tearing the Earth apart and what happens next? You and your crew are shot at by some natives claiming that you are violating their air space. As your ship tears itself apart and plummets to the desert floor you know that your only chance of survival will be to pick up the pieces of your communications array that are now conveniently scattered across the driest most self-destructing climate you have ever seen.

All you have to do is find and set up the four parts of the communications array and signal the mother ship to come heal this planet and get you out of here. You will have to navigate around the perilous hazards, avoid snipers who want you gone, secret agents who are stealing your technology, crazy mad scientists who want to perform experiments on you, and a completely different alien race who may even abduct you. Work together efficiently as a team and you will avoid a Naturally Disastrous fate! If you become mutated, you turn against your former allies.

The game is played on a randomized map, with randomly placed tokens. Each turn, the active player must roll to activate a disaster, and then has 3 actions per turn (move, probe, etc.) Combat is resolved with dice. As each part of the communications array is found, it must be transported to one of the corners of the map.

item.description:
A memory game to frazzle the mind, a cross between memory game and rummy. 60 tactile counters, in 4 bright colours, numbered from 1-13, and 8 black counters can be used as anything.

Turn the counters face down and shuffle them around, arrange in a grid of 6 rows and 10 columns for easier play, leave random for harder play, suitable for 2+ players.

The active player turns over 3 counters of their choice, and the aim is to make a run of three consecutive numbers in the same colour, or a set of three numbers the same. If the numbers do not make a set or run, the counters are turned back over face down and the next player choices three counters to turn over, to make a set or a run. If a player turns over three counters making a set or a run, they take these from the middle and place them face up by themselves, and this gives them a score. The black counters have no numerical value, but can be used as anything to make up sets and runs with the other counters turned in a go.

The more counters you can rumemba which have been played, the greater your ability to make runs and sets. The counters all score for face value, and each player adds up the total number of points they have from the sets and runs they have won.

Do you really know the origins of the French language? Latin and Greek words are everywhere in the French language. With this family game, use Latin and Greek roots to find the corresponding French words. If you have for example MANUS, "hand" in Latin, you can find "manucure", "manual" or "manufacture". Depending on the difficulty or frequency derivative you will find, you score more points. No panic, no need to be a distinguished Latin or Greek scholar to participate! You just have to arm themselves with good humor and a competitive spirit! An addictive game for the whole family.
Etymolinguo, the game that revives the ancient languages!
Published in partnership with the site www.arretetonchar.fr

Material: 70 double-sided Latin/Greek cards, 1 hourglass, 1 pencil, 1 notebook

Rules of the game: the game master draws a card, reads the word (Latin and Greek) and his team will give as fast as possible French words derived from the Latin or Greek root. The more complicated is the word derivative, the more it gives points to his team.
Thus for GENUS ("species" in Latin), you can give: général (1 point), genèse (2 points), or gentleman (3 points).
The first team that reaches 15 points wins!

---

Connaissez-vous vraiment les origines du français ? Les mots latins et grecs sont partout dans la langue française. Avec ce jeu familial, partez des racines latines et grecques et trouvez les mots français correspondants. Si on vous dit par exemple MANUS, "la main" en latin, vous pourrez proposer « manucure », « manuel » ou « manufacture ». Selon la difficulté ou la fréquence du dérivé que vous trouverez, vous marquerez davantage de points. Pas de panique, pas besoin d’être un latiniste ou un helléniste émérite pour participer ! Il suffit juste de s’armer de bonne humeur et d’un esprit de compétition ! Un jeu addictif pour toute la famille.
Etymolinguo, le jeu qui ressuscite les langues anciennes !
Edité en partenariat avec le site www.arretetonchar.fr

Ce jeu d’étymologie est constitué d’un ensemble de cartes, d’un sablier, d’un carnet de notes et de son crayon.
Règles du jeu par équipe : le maître du jeu pioche une carte, énonce le mot (latin ou grec) et son équipe devra donner en un minimum de temps des mots français dérivés de ces racines latines ou grecques. Plus le mot dérivé est compliqué et plus il rapporte à son équipe.
Ainsi pour AMO ("aimer" en latin), on peut donner : amour (1 point), amant (2 points), ou amouracher (3 points).
La première équipe qui arrive à 15 points remporte la partie !

Be the first to reach the finish line and win, but beware the falling stars! 3-D Action adds to the traditional game play of Snakes & Ladders. Contents: 3D plastic playing board with pop-up dice in middle, 2 Detachable ladders & 4 Colored marbles. Fun from top to button. Lalaloopsy - Sew Magical! Sew Cute!

Find it first, find it fast, find your fun! Card ‘N’ Go Seek is the game that delivers get-out-of-your-seat scavenger hunt fun for the whole family! At the count of three, everyone dashes off to retrieve an item revealed on one of the cards. The first player to get back with the correct type of item wins the matching card! Players have fun deciding for themselves what the cards mean. For example, finding something SWEET could be a lollipop or a picture of your great aunt Helen! Interpreting the cards really lets your personality shine. The first player to win one card of each color OR three cards of the same color wins the game! Every new environment invites new ways to play – the world is your game! Includes 150 cards, portable plastic case and instructions. Colors and decorations may vary.

In Efterklok, a.k.a. Hinterher ist man immer schlauer, you answer five questions in a row. After you've answered, every player learns how many correct answers you gave, but not which questions were correct. The same five questions are now presented to the player after you, and they can choose to either copy your answers or give their own in the hope of scoring more points. As long as no one has answered all of the questions correctly, this process continues until everyone but the questioner has had a chance to answer the questions. Thus, if you stay alert and can read the other players well, you might be able to win the game even if didn't know many of the answers to begin with!

Efterklok comes with more than five hundred entertaining, interesting, and educational questions.

Hera, tired of Zeus' infidelity, decides to take her revenge and releases the Titans on Mount Olympus. In the ensuing battle, the power liberated by the combatants ignites in a combustion that shatters the Earth. In the ensuing deflagration, the weakest gods are obliterated, rendered down into the small fragments of power that constituted their being. The stronger ones were able to resist total annihilation but even their prodigious power could not save them entirely. As the survivors fell from the broken mountain, the shards of their divinity and the remnants of those that did not survive were scattered to the 4 corners of a now broken world.

As they awoke, each god found themselves to be but a shadow of their former selves. They were still mighty, stronger than any mortal that yet walked but they were no longer all powerful, no longer immortal. Each one could sense the fragments of power that had now fallen to the Earth and that by collecting these they could regain their former grandeur and, if they could but amass enough, stand at the front of a new Pantheon, reshaped in their image.

The world around them suffered as much as they did, the power released during the epic battle had ignited a cataclysm that reduced the beautiful land of Greece to a barren wasteland. Athens burns, Crete has sunken below the waves of the roiling seas and the immortal mount Olympus is now an ash covered wreck of its former glory. But this Event has not only affected the mortal realms. The underworld trembled from the blow even as a legion of fresh souls ran down the river Styx. Would that have been the extent of the underworld's involvement however...

Hades, having lost the majority of his power, no longer holds sway over the Underworld. The gates of hell are open and even though the River Styx prevents the weakest souls from regaining the mortal world, the strongest warriors, the mightiest heroes and the most vicious monsters have managed to claw their way back up the Styx and back to the surface.

As a new power struggle breaks out, Gods summon mortal survivors, returned heroes and reborn monsters to their side in their hunt for the shards of their lost power.

In Mythic Battles: Pantheon, it is these clashes between warbands, in the midst of a post-apocalyptic ancient Greece, that are the focal point of the game. Choose your God, draft your warband and take the fight to your enemies with the might of the most powerful beings from Greek mythology at your back.

name.value: Brave and Noble Fights Expansion: The Battles of Foochow and Pung-do Island

item.description:
Brave and Noble Fights Expansion: The Battles of Foochow and Pung-do Island. This expansion game portrays the first battle of the 1894-95 Sino-Japanese War of Pung-do Island, and extends the period covered to the climactic battle of Foochow of the 1884 Sino-French War.

The historical Battle of Foochow can be played as a stand-alone game. However, to play the mini-game Battle of Pung-do and the many variants of Foochow and other “what if” battles of the Sino-French War you will need a copy of Brave and Noble Fights: The Battles of the Yalu and Wei-Hai-Wei.

item.description:
Four Wizards is a new version of a classic card-shedding game. Players draw and discard their way to an empty hand, laying down a variety of cards designed around a medieval theme. Each deck comes with 72 cards and supports a game of 2-4 players. Included are 48 Medieval Unit Cards (4 Colored Factions: Blue Cross, Green Star, Red & Gold, and Purple Chevron).

In addition to the 48 Unit cards, there are 16 Wizards (4 different classes for each colored faction), and 6 Plague Cards. Plague Cards do not belong to any color; therefore, they cannot be discarded, ONLY PURGED. Plague Cards were created to prevent you from getting rid of all your cards. There are several ways to remove these cards from your hand (see Wizard Cards). Part of the fun is discovering these various methods of "purging" the Plague.

Wizard Cards are played in the same manner as the other Colored Units. For example, a Blue Wizard can be played on top of any Blue Unit or on top of any other Wizard. There are four types of Wizard Cards, each with their own unique action.

Swap-A-Hand Wizard - When you play this Wizard, swap your hand with the hand of another player. The choice of which player to Swap-A- Hand with is yours. Once the “swap” has occurred, play continues to the next player in turn.

Draw Two Wizard - When you play this Wizard, the next player must draw 2 cards. The player who draws the additional cards will still be able to play their turn. If they do not have a playable card after Drawing Two, they must continue to Draw until they draw a card that can be played. A turn is determined complete when a card has been played.

Purge-A-Card Wizard - When you play this Wizard, you may discard ANY card of your choice from your hand. Place the card of your choice facedown on the tabletop, thus removing it from the game completely. The card has now been PURGED.

Purge-The-Plague Wizard - When you play this Wizard, you may discard ONLY Plague Cards from your hand. However there is no limit to how many Plague Cards you can discard. Place the Plague Card(s) face up on the tabletop, thus removing it from the game completely. *The two "Purge" Wizard cards are the ONLY cards that can remove Plague Cards from your hand and therefore the game. Also important is the ability of the "Purge-A-Card" Wizard to remove ANY card from the game. The ability to remove Any card allows various opportunities to develop. In fact, sometimes the best play might not be to PURGE a Plague card. The choice is yours...

Become a master Necromancer!

Cadaver is a card game in which players must use a variety of arcane resources to reanimate a series of cadavers. Each cadaver has a resource cost which players must spend to re-animate the corpse. Resources are drawn from a shared deck. One deck can be used by up to 3 players. Adding a second deck allows up to 6 players to compete for best necromancer!

Each player takes a number of cards from a single deck looking for corpses to reanimate, collecting arcane resources and accomplices, coffin locks and keys or terrifying ghouls. The player with the most corpses raised by dawn wins the game!
